visualization_prompt: Generate a 3D column chart showing comparative fruit consumption patterns between demographic groups using depth-enhanced categorical grouping
visualization_explanation: The dataset contains two-dimensional categorical data comparing weekly fruit consumption across 12 categories. Variables include nominal fruit types (independent variable) and ratio-scale consumption metrics (dependent variable). Synthetic data was generated with μ=3.9, σ=1.4 for adults and μ=3.6, σ=1.7 for seniors, maintaining domain plausibility through USDA dietary guidelines reference. The 3D column format enhances between-group comparisons while minimizing perspective distortion through controlled alpha/beta angles. Depth cues leverage Cairo's depth perception principles without compromising Tufte's data-ink ratio. Color coding follows Weber-Fechner law for luminance contrast, with blue/orange providing 4.5:1 contrast ratio for accessibility. Trend analysis reveals adults show preference for grapes (x̄=6.2) while seniors consume more apples (x̄=6.1), aligning with texture preference research in food science.
